TI  - Effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction on anxiety and depression:
      a systematic review and meta-analysis.
AU  - Smith, John A
AU  - Jones, Alice B
AU  - Williams, Carol
FAU - Smith, John Arthur
FAU - Jones, Alice Barbara
FAU - Williams, Carol
AB  - Background: Mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) has been widely applied
      in clinical settings. Objective: To systematically review the evidence for MBSR
      on anxiety and depression outcomes. Methods: We searched PubMed, CINAHL, and
      PsycINFO through December 2022. Results: 42 RCTs were included. MBSR showed
      significant effects on anxiety (d=0.52) and depression (d=0.48). Conclusion:
      MBSR is effective for reducing anxiety and depression in clinical populations.

TI  - Cognitive behavioral therapy versus pharmacotherapy for major depression:
      a randomized controlled trial.
AU  - Brown, Michael
AU  - Garcia, Sofia
FAU - Brown, Michael Thomas
FAU - Garcia, Sofia Elena
AB  - This randomized controlled trial compared CBT with antidepressant medication
      in 320 adults with major depression. Both treatments were effective at 12 weeks.
      CBT showed superior long-term outcomes at 2-year follow-up.
